author: Karen Percy
title: Kokoda Track's last 'Fuzzy Wuzzy Angel' meets with veteran 'for last time'
text:
Map: Melbourne 3000 
Havala Laula wears the slouch hat with pride. 
Seventy-five years ago he served with Australians near his village on the Kokoda Track in Papua New Guinea as war raged around them, fetching ammunition, food, water and other supplies for the allies in 1942. 
The 91-year-old is the last of the Kokoda "Fuzzy Wuzzy Angels", the name given to the local carriers of WWII. 
He has made his first journey across the seas, but it has also taken him back through the decades to a time when he and his fellow Fuzzy Wuzzy Angels were crucial in getting wounded soldiers out of the jungle — soldiers such as Lieutenant Alan "Kanga" Moore from the 39th Battalion. 
In an emotional reunion, the men exchanged gratitude and shared their experiences. 
"I am old, you are old — we meet for the last time," Mr Laula told Mr Moore through an interpreter. 
As a 21-year-old serving at Kokoda, Lt Moore got very sick — contracting malaria, dengue fever, hookworm, dysentery, hepatitis — and had to be taken out on a stretcher. 
"He might have carried me out," Lt Moore said as Mr Laula held his hand tightly. 
"If it hadn't have been for the carriers of the Kokoda Track ... I might not have got out." 
He described the dedication of the Fuzzy Wuzzy Angels in shading the wounded with banana leaves, giving them water, and finding them native foods to eat as they made their way to clearing stations where the patients could be transferred for treatment. 
"They were martyrs ... they really were angels," Mr Moore said. 'Nasty' dreams ended after revisiting Kokoda Photo: Alan Moore believes the locals who helped the Allies were treated badly by the Australian Government. (ABC News: Karen Percy) 
Mr Laula speaks in a soft voice but his words are strong. 
"I witnessed a big massacre, one of the last at Kokoda," he said with pain in his eyes. 
Mr Laula said there were two types of people back then — the enemy, who attacked his village, and the good people, the Australian diggers who looked after the local people. 
Since the war, Mr Moore has been to PNG four times, including a visit in 2012 to mark the 70th anniversary of the Kokoda battles. 
He was an honoured guest on that occasion and was surprised by the appearance of his granddaughter, who like many Australians these days took a pilgrimage along the Kokoda Track. 
The visit also helped him deal with the trauma suffered all those years ago. 
"They didn't tell me [she was coming]", he said with a smile. 
"My memories have never gone back to the bad things [of war]. All the nasty dreams stopped at that point." 
He remembers the good times, like knocking coconuts off the trees. 'They were treated very badly' 
Mr Moore became an executive at Heinz after the war, and since retiring has volunteered at a Mornington aged-care facility where he now lives. 
For the past 15 years he has been funding the education of a young villager at Kokoda and has assisted in raising money for kindergartens at numerous villages. 
"Their grandfathers are the ones who helped us," he said. 
It is his way of giving back to a people he thinks should have been better treated by the Australian Government. 
"I think they were treated very badly. They were promised things they never got. They were lucky if they got a cup of rice a day," he said. 
"We wouldn't have won the campaign without them."
